comments.commentBody:
And it is continually printed in articles in U.S. newspapers how President al-Assad uses chemical weapons upon his own people, although never proved. And it is continually asserted how dictators are characterized by persecuting any intellectuals, any thinking people, lest they become a danger to a despotic regime. However that kind of anti-intellectualism seems to characterize America today, and it's been getting worse every year.
If you actually want freedom of speech and thought maybe you would be better off under Assad ! And maybe that's why they are still trying to completely destroy that government, It is not in keeping with the kind of 'Big Brother-ism' that America is trying to spread, in its grossest arrogance. The Republicans, and the Democrats, have both been brainwashed by the current purveyors of the new political ideology, which rejects thinking, and rejects any true kind of democracy. And it is beholden to the richest interests, almost anything about it wrong.

In 1941 Adolf Hitler wrote these words to Mussolini to explain why Russia had to be dealt with:

"I am writing this letter to you at a moment when months of anxious deliberation and continuous nerve-racking waiting are ending in the hardest decision of my life. I belie(ve)f—after seeing the latest Russian situation map and after appraisal of numerous other reports—that I cannot take the responsibility for waiting longer, and above all, I believe that there is no other way of obviating this danger—unless it be further waiting, which, however, would necessarily lead to disaster in this or the next year at the latest.

"The situation: England has lost this war. With the right of the drowning person, she grasps at every straw ... directing the glances of the British warmongers continually to the place from which they tried to start the war: to Soviet Russia.

"..., Soviet Russia and England, are equally interested in a Europe fallen into ruin, rendered prostrate by a long war. ... there is evident in Soviet Russia a consistent trend, which, even if cleverly and cautiously, is nevertheless reverting firmly to the old Bolshevist tendency to expansion of the Soviet State ..."

Netanyahu is hardly an Adolf Hitler, regardless of the irony, but what is similar is that characteristic in obsessive Authoritarians to rigidly define their opponents and do so by exaggeration and all manner of flawed argument.

And an obsessive Authoritarian Netanyahu is.
.

I can't speak for Prof. Krugman but from reading his columns regularly I think he would say that monetary policy, when you are up against the zero lower bound is a poor substitute for an active fiscal policy.

We've got no demand, that's why there's no interest.

We've got idle labor, much of it extremely well trained, most of it at the very least moderately disciplined. We've got record amounts of idle capital.

We've got dilapidated infrastructure.

The sound thing to do is a strong stimulus spending to employ all that capital and labor, and our infrastructure needs are the kind that generate returns on money spent.

What we have is a Republican party that want's to ruin the US for not awarding them with control of all political power, and when in power ruins the US and much of the world along with it. So no more stimulus.

In 2009 Prof. Krugman was vocal in suggesting to Obama to go long, hard and deep on a BIG stimulus bill. Instead they went short, easy and shallow.

At the same time South Korea implemented a stimulus = to 25% of GNP over 4 years. They grew 0.2% in 2009! 6% in 2010 w/ 3% unemployment, in 1st quarter 2010 local press referred to the 2009 recession as ancient history. The same size % in the U.S. would have been $4 trillion over 4 years. Anything less than $1 trillion wasn't really serious. We got $800 billion + cash for clunkers + QE. The stimulus stopped the free fall immediately but didn't reverse things back into normal. Its been a long hard slog.

It was totally worth it for the nice memory of good ol' Sociology 101 and the principle of parsimony, one of my favorite words.
Group of dispatchers was clever, though not a very pleasant thought.

Unless she attempts to put a hijab on you or anyone else, she IS observing her religion privately. Wearing the hijab doesn't oblige her to answer to you or anyone else. You're mistaken as to what freedom of religion is.
You must have inside information because I did not see anything in this article stating kids from the hood were smoking marijuana.

Three of Syracuse's starters grew up in the projects,  None of the three them grew up with fathers.  If you have to be told that Boeheim deals with  kids with tough backgrounds, you don't know basketball and you don't know how to read between the lines.

Folks need a reality check.  Kids from the hood smart enough to get into Syracuse under NCAA guidelines nonetheless take drugs, modest amounts of money and cut corners in the classroom, all under Boeheim's watch.  The coach is not part of it but doesn't do enough to stop it.  What it comes down to is that he was a lenient disciplinarian and the NCAA only believes in tough discipline.  Seems to me that reasonable people can differ on this one.  If my kid smoked marijuana, picked up $500 by selling it to friends and got caught cheating once, I'd still let him come home for the holidays.

realist
You are right and correct, but we have been having increasingly serious events take place at school in America, and the best-seller 'Nineteen Minutes' by Jodi Picoult based on a true tragedy comes to mind. It gave this reader pause to think 'what if?'.

When a couple came from Kenya a few years ago with their two young daughters ages 8 and 10, their mother told me that there was an incident on the school bus, a confrontation where the eldest stood her ground against a 'perfectly angelic-looking' bully, which got nipped in the bud, after parent and teacher were to discuss this with care and deliberation.

Let's start teaching our children at home that any kind of bullying is wrong, no matter when or why. We can try so as not to cry.

Kids are mean. Middle school, high school doesn't matter. Muslim, catholic, jewish, Asian, black, african-american, spanish, irish, Italian. Doesn't matter. For all of us, it's been there done that. Been happening for years, gonna continue for years. Get over it. Kids are kids.

DiBlasio's Arguement: respect every culture. Don't offend anyone. So much for 1st amendment rights.

Question: what happened to the concept of America as a melting pot. Everyone comes together as Americans first, then retains elements of their other culture? But America and Americanism first. Lose that, and there is no more America. Remember that.

I grew up in NYC and now live in a suburb.  I belive you are correct.  Unfortunately the media doesn't like telling "good" stories and so only knows how to promote division and controversy, mostly created, to promote and sell itself.  Don't listen to mainstream media.  It's all self serving.
Then the schools must request donations.

You mention several things, and I do believe this relates to childhood obesity, bad lifelong habits -- "indoorsiness" -- fear of the outdoors and nature. Children who have an exaggerated idea of real life risk (i.e., "If I walk to school, I may be KIDNAPPED BY A STRANGER!").

It must be contributing to things like ADD and ADHD, as children have a deep need to run and play which is being suppressed by adults in authority (out of laziness or exaggerated fears). Meanwhile, we have a generation here who plays video games on the couch, and not outdoors.

I once found my nephews, inside playing a basketball video game on their fancy new Playstation -- on a gorgeous June day -- while outside, they had their own actual basketball hoop on the garage! But they vastly preferred to play the video game over experience a real game in their real yard. No air conditioning out there, dontcha know.

I am sure this contributes no end to childhood problems across the board. But adults too are lazy and "indoorsy" today -- and see nothing wrong with it, and if you mention it, they get angry at you. There are folks to whom "let's go outside for a walk!" are fighting words.

I was in elementary school in the northern Midwest in the 1960s. It was considerably colder than in New York. We had three recesses a day, and with the very rare exceptions of pouring rain, we went out in all weather. Most of us also played outdoors after school. Guess what? Obesity was rare-to-unheard of as was attention deficit disorder. The first person I ever met with asthma was as an adult in New York. You're not doing the children any big favors keeping them indoors!
If Cuomo & the charter schools have their way the school day will be nothing but test prep!!
I believe that game is known as "kickball".

I grew up in Minnesota and Wisconsin, and we walked to school in all weather, so on most days, there was no reason to deny us recess, although we were occasionally kept indoors. (I was too young to know what the actual threshold was.) On the days we were kept indoors, we did square dancing or folk dancing.

During warmer weather, we played on the playground equipment, but in the Wisconsin town where I spent part of my childhood, we played an informal version of soccer that had only two rules: don't touch the ball with your hands, and kick toward the other team's goal. (This was at a time when most Americans didn't know what soccer was.) Yes, we played it in the snow.

I am a bit confused. The implementation of the policy is at the school level. My daughter, a 3rd grader in a NYC public school reported to me that she has been outside for recess most days this month. She tells me on cold days she has a option to stay inside, if she chooses, but mostly she is outside.
These schools pay janitorial staff who are responsible to do that. It is not the children's or parent's responsibility.

Really?  Do u have any kids?  Kids go out in 20 degrees in t-shirts.  Mine yell at me.when I 6ell them to put on a coat.  Sweatshirts are more than enuff.  And what influence does a family's financial status determine whether an entire class has recess?  Are we saying if 1 kid can't afford what u think is adequate clothing we keep the entire class in?  Wake up.  The needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few or the one.  Don't make an entire class suffer.
Joe Paper: You want them to clean up Pottstown?  Your comment is as clear as it is nuanced.

When I lived in Fairbanks, Alaska, from 1971–1984, the criterion for canceling school was -50º F.  For recess, I'm not sure; but in Alaska, where my two sons were born, one doesn't worry so much about the ambient temperature is so much as one is concerned about whether one is protected against it.
Wait for it...but that would be "unfair" to those who don't have proper attire. Better by far, the thinking goes, to restrict everyone so as to guard a few.

There you go. When I taught in central Florida (and it does get chilly there) I gave my kids' outgrown hoodie jackets to my friend the kindergarten teacher, who had several kids who never dressed appropriately. It was sad, one little girl begged to take hers home so she wouldn't be cold at home. My friend, sadly, had to say no because the hoodie would have disappeared and not been brought back to school.

For kids who don't have appropriate outdoor clothing, either keep them inside or provide them with outdoor gear and let them out.  For kids who do have appropriate outdoor clothing, let them outside for recess.  The fresh air, sunshine, and exercise will help to boost their immune systems, allow them to burn off excess energy, and help them to concentrate better in the classroom.

We recently lost TWO CONSECUTIVE days of school to "snow days" -- an option that is greatly abused by union school employees for their own ends (a free paid holiday!). As it was a Thursday and Friday, miraculously this resulted in a 4 day weekend!

It was very cold, but nothing dangerous. In fact, they decided to close based on reports of low temps -- but the actual DAYS it turned out were very sunny and not windy, so they were not all that unpleasant. We had colder, more windy days that were WORSE, but the schools ran out of snow days.

So the teachers & administrators got a 4 day weekend (paid) -- while children LOST two days of instruction. As snow days, they are not required to be made up. Meanwhile, all normal folks slogged off to work....as normal. (Thank goodness, so the teachers could all use those days to go shopping, eat out, attend movies, etc.)

And these wussified kids are going to hold off ISIS? the world must be falling on the floor laughing at us.

Then there's the school in Kip's Bay that has stopped giving younger students homework and asks them to go play instead.  Apparently, parents there are up-in-arms over that policy fearing their children won't learn enough.

Are you sure about not making up the snow days? All the school districts I am familiar with have to make up snow days at the end of the year, or sometimes during spring break.
And as for the teachers you disparage - they are not in charge of making decisions about snow days. Those decisions are usually made by the superintendent.

The wussification of America, in all its glory, continues.  Can't leave kids unsupervised until they are of age to enter military service (thank goodness they are prepared for that because mom has hovered over them until age 18 and therfore they have learned how to be independent), no recess, too cold (we just had one of those, in new jersey); snow day because the forecast calls for snow.  The list goes on and on.  Just fold up the tents and call it a day.  Hello ISIS?  It's America, we surrender.  Come on in.

Our wee Vermont school's rule about outdoor play is that if it is above 15 degrees, the kids go out, They bundle up and go out and play, and sled, and build forts. My young kid is no worse for the wear, quite the contrary, it is his favorite part of the day. And there are programs all over Vermont giving winter outerwear to those in need.

Oh yeah, that will totally work.  I can see myself out there in the school yard now, the school yard that's the size of a 1/2 a city block and covered in snow.  I've got my 28 first graders lined up with their school-purchased kiddy sized snow shovels.  On my command, they all begin to dig in perfect unison, just like I've trained them to all morning, right after teaching them how to read, write their lower case letters and subtract…..Never mind those kids that I work with who have physical or fine motor delays, they'll catch on when they see how much fun their classmates are having!…….only someone who has never worked with children or is a complete idiot would make such a suggestion.

I'm suspect the academics and other staff involved in educational and/or research pursuits and even non-basketball/football sports at SU feel like hostages and victims. Many are undoubtedly but secretly scornful of the dominating influence of those sports and of the multi-million dollar remunerated coaches and athletic director. The same must be true at other such universities. It's somewhat parallel to the wealth gap and money-influenced politics plagues.
If they don't fire the coach, then Syracuse should remove the word "university" from the name of the institution

Why oh why with all the negative waves? We on the left coast have to deal with Santa Ana winds which rip between 40 and 60 mph and can raise the outside temperatures from the low 40s to mid 90s in a couple of hours. Many school age children run this gauntlet during the school year. Hydrate them let them run and make sure they don't get a bloody nose. Oh and when it rains we usually let them out in it!
The Chief a third grade teacher

This is a two-fold problem; school administrators are forced -- by idiot lawsuits and rules -- to avoid ANY situation that could remotely have the slightest risk. (Never mind the lifelong risk of raising completely sedentary kids!) They are terrified of a lawsuit, should someone's "precious snowflake" skin a knee.

I mention above that families in my own neighborhood will drive children to school -- distances of 4 homes! or less than 500 ft! -- because they literally cannot imagine a child taking an umbrella and walking in the rain. If you say anything about this, they bite your head off.

As for the teachers: they don't want to go outdoors either! so much easier to sit inside, playing Candy Crush on your iPhone or checking your Facebook page, than encouraging games or going outside. God forbid, you might have to put a coat on!

My kids went to a school where the principal would not allow them to run on the playground because as he told me when I confronted him "they might fall and skin their knees."  This was over 30 years ago.

AT my children's public elementary school in Brooklyn every manner of excuse is used to prevent the children from going outside.  It is always too cold, or too icy, or too wet. If it rained the day before and there is a single puddle of water that is enough.  Any spot of ice or snow means it is "unsafe."  The principal blames DOE policies.  But I believe the recess staff - who are not teachers - do not want to go outside and it is far easier just to herd the kids into the auditorium for a movie the kids have seen countless times.  And when they are allowed out, the kids are not allowed to run, use balls, or engage in any activity that could be in any way harmful.  Like in the the Diary of a Wimpy Kid, the the kids are told they cannot run, but cannot sit - they "have to stay active."  Parents complain but get nowhere.

A Torontonian informs me that they are much heartier than the article indicates. -25C, as stated in the link provided for Ontario school guidelines,  is equal to NEGATIVE 13 Fahrenheit,  not 13 above. :)
